content.title: Part 1: Definitions of Energy Poverty and Fuel Poverty

content.text: Part 1 Overview

In previous sections, we learned that millions of people lack access to essential energy services like electricity and modern cooking technologies. However, simply having access does not guarantee that energy can be utilized.

Millions of people around the world struggle to keep their homes lit and heated, often forced to choose between buying food or fuel. Many women will rely on polluting energy sources for daily household tasks, conserving what little modern energy they have for when the family gathers at night. Thousands of communities resort to informal grid connections, despite the health risks, because they are socially excluded and unable to live in connected neighborhoods. All these individuals are experiencing different forms of energy and fuel poverty.
Energy Poverty (EP)

Energy poverty is defined differently across regions, reflecting diverse socio-economic and energy access realities. Globally, the Multi-Dimensional Energy Poverty Index (MEPI) presents energy poverty as the lack of access to modern energy services that are essential for human development such as lighting, cooking, communication, and access to household appliances and is best understood as a multidimensional issue (Nussbaumer et al., 2012). In the African continent, the lack of access to adequate and sufficient energy services constitutes a severe development problem. The main focus when it comes to energy poverty in Africa revolves around addressing governance issues, outdated infrastructure, high energy costs, and limited access, especially in rural and remote regions (Filho et al., 2024). Meanwhile, in Latin America, energy poverty denotes “the state in which individuals or households do not have access to energy services that are reasonably priced, dependable, and environmentally friendly. This idea incorporates multiple dimensions, such as the price, accessibility, reliability, and quality of energy services” (Filho et al., 2024). In contrast, the European Union focuses on affordability and infrastructure, defining energy poverty as t “lack of access to essential energy services, caused by factors like low-income, high-energy expenditure, and poor energy efficiency of home” ( EU, 2023). These varied definitions highlight the importance of context-specific approaches to addressing energy poverty worldwide.
Fuel Poverty (FP)

The concept of fuel poverty emphasizes on the critical aspect of affordability concerning access to essential energy services. According to one influential definition, fuel poverty occurs when individuals or households face challenges in meeting the costs of heating, cooling, cooking, and powering their homes, leading to adverse consequences for their well-being and quality of life (Moore, 2012).

content.title: Part 2: Root Causes and Reproduciton of Inequalities

content.text: Part 2 Overview

The concepts of energy and fuel poverty are entry points to better understand the multifaceted challenges associated with sustainable and inclusive energy access. EP/FP is not a standalone issue. It is intertwined with multiple dimensions of poverty and inequality and ultimately contributes to a viscous circle that perpetuates such poverty and inequality. Inclusive energy access, specifically, means ensuring that all people—regardless of gender, age, or circumstance—have equitable access to energy services that reduce risks and create opportunities, while addressing diverse needs. In this section you will understand their root causes and how they perpetuate inequalities.

Image above: During heatwaves, many children in camps in northwest Syria are at risk of severe heat stroke and dehydration, as they spend most of their time outside their plastic tents (OCHA et al., 2022, pg.32). Non-insulated, poor-quality shelters, ongoing political instability and forced displacement are some of the deep-rooted causes that trap these communities in energy poverty.
Click to reveal the ROOT CAUSES OF fuel POVERTY

Fuel poverty metrics often consider factors such as household income, energy prices, and energy efficiency, providing a quantitative framework for evaluating the extent of energy affordability challenges in a given population. By emphasizing the affordability root cause, it provides a nuanced lens through which policymakers, researchers, and advocates can unpack the socio-economic barriers that hinder individuals from accessing clean and reliable energy.

The intersection of EP/FP with multiple dimensions of poverty and inequality paints a complex picture that requires comprehensive solutions. Recognizing these intricate connections is pivotal for crafting comprehensive solutions that address the root causes and interconnected nature of energy poverty and broader social inequalities.

content.title: Part 3: How are Energy and Fuel Poverty measured?

content.text: Part 3 Overview
EP/FP is measured using various indexes that take into account factors such as energy access, affordability, and reliability.
EP/FP Indexes

Help policymakers and researchers understand the extent of energy poverty in different regions and design targeted interventions Generate valuable data that supports resource allocation and program design for energy-deprived communities while facilitating research and advocacy efforts to raise awareness of energy access challenges. May include surveys or assessments that consider individual-level factors such as household income, energy consumption patterns, and living conditions. These detailed insights are pivotal for the tailoring of policies and interventions, ensuring that they resonate with the specific needs of the populations they aim to serve.
EP indexes/tracking reports
Multidimensional Energy Poverty Index (MEPI)
MEPI provides a comprehensive assessment of energy poverty by considering multiple factors simultaneously: access, affordability, reliability, and quality.
EP indexes/tracking reports
Poor People's Energy Outlook (PPEO)

The PPEO was launched in 2010 by the Global NGO Practical Action to shine a light on energy access from the perspectives of the poor. The series challenges the energy sector’s focus on energy resources, supply and large scale infrastructure projects; emphasizing instead that it is energy services which matter most to poor people, and that decentralised approaches are the best way to achieve universal energy access. PPEO 2019 is a compilation and update of the previous three editions of the PPEO series, on energy access planning (2016), finance (2017) and delivery (2018). This set of infographics presents the report's methodology, call to action and key recommendations on clean cooking and electricity. See more: PPEO website To complete this information with more recent data, consult the 2024 WEO, especially the section on Affordability and people-centered transitions. (IEA., 2014) Image below - Bottom-up Methodologies Exploring National-Scale Energy Access (source: PPEO 2019 Report Infographics)

The incorporation of geospatial data and analysis involves mapping energy access disparities by location, enabling the identification of areas with the most acute energy deficits. Such geospatial insights facilitate the development of precisely targeted interventions, ensuring that underserved communities benefit effectively from energy access initiatives. Data is increasingly shared online using interactive visuals with data points often made available for downloading.
Example of interactive map: LIKELIHOOD A SETTLEMENT IS LIT (HREA)

The HREA Map utilize advanced satellite image analysis to explore energy poverty classifications across the developing world. This tool combines high-resolution nighttime and daytime satellite imagery to assess light output signatures. Data is gathered over up to 3,000 nights across human settlements, providing a comprehensive view of energy access across different regions.

EP/FP indexes increasingly consider individual-level factors such as household income, energy consumption patterns, and living conditions in order to help ensure that interventions resonate with the specific needs of the populations they aim to serve. Energy access statistics are becoming easier to understand and obtain with of use of online, interactive maps and charts, and the provision of downloadable data sets.

content.title: Case Study: Moldova

content.text: Case Study RBEC: Energy Vulnerability Reduction Fund (EVRF)
Context

In 2022, Moldova faced n unprecedented crisis resulting from a combination of structural and contextual factors: The country’s energy dependency on fossil fuels, the global rise in energy prices, and geopolitical instability caused by the war in Ukraine. Moldova is highly dependent on energy imports, with over 70% of its electricity supply sourced from the Cuciurgan Power Station located in the Transnistrian region, and the remainder from imports from Ukraine. In November 2022, gas deliveries from Russia dropped by 49%, triggering an electricity production deficit and a rapid rise in energy prices ( UNDP., 2024). Electricity tariffs quadrupled, leading to inflationary pressures that severely affected household budgets. According to UNDP estimates, 71% of Moldovan households fell into the most energy-vulnerable category, spending more than 90% of their disposable income (after covering minimum subsistence needs) on heating and energy during the cold season. The energy crisis risked pushing the national poverty rate from 11% to 35%, affecting an additional 640,000 people.
UNDP's solution
The Approach

To address this crisis, the Moldovan government, with technical support from UNDP, introduced an innovative social protection measure called the Energy Vulnerability Reduction Fund (EVRF). The EVRF aimed to provide emergency energy compensation to households while promoting long-term goals of energy efficiency and sustainability in the country’s energy system. The program consisted in direct on-bill subsidies paid to energy suppliers, that effectively helped reduce consumers' energy costs without requiring upfront payments or reimbursements from the beneficiaries. The initiative was supported by a digital infrastructure called the Energy Vulnerability Information System (EVIS), designed to manage registration and verification processes efficiently.
Targeting Mechanism

The EVRF used an algorithm to classify households into vulnerability tiers based on the ratio of energy expenses to disposable income. Initially, five categories were used, from very high vulnerability to none. By March 2023, over 763,000 households, representing around 75% of Moldova’s total population, had registered. The level of compensation varied by vulnerability level and energy type.
Impact

This initiative contributed to significantly reduce energy poverty in the nation. For natural gas users in the highest vulnerability category, the occurrence of energy poverty dropped by 83 percentage points, while for electricity users in the same group, it decreased by 71 percentage points. The programme also helped reduce income poverty by 43% among very highly vulnerable households. The Moldova case demonstrates how targeted, data-driven approaches can effectively mitigate the effects of an energy crisis on energy poverty, while laying improving long term resilience. Key success factors included the integration of digital systems for eligibility verification, differentiated subsidy design based on vulnerability levels, and complementary programmes such as smart meter installations and appliance replacement schemes for efficiency. The EVRF’s success highlights the value of adaptable social protection systems to respond to crises and the importance of combining short-term relief with structural energy transition goals to reduce energy poverty.
Conclusion

The Solar for Health initiative in Yemen has resulted in positive impacts in Yemen by improving healthcare services and promoting sustainable development, including the creation of green job opportunities and skills development.
(Optional) Learn more about UNDP's Solar for Health Initiative

As the Solar for Health initiative has been implemented in multiple countries across Africa and the Arab States, it has been proven to successfully bring positive impacts to developing countries. UNDP has also supported the assessment of innovative financing mechanisms to scale this program in Malawi, Zimbabwe, Liberia, Namibia, and Zambia. The coordination platform financing model is scalable across geographies with specific features that can be tailored to local specificities. The platform can harmonize stakeholders’ interventions, such as UN agencies, donors, DFIs, private sector, and government entities, across countries in linking energy and health sectors. Furthermore, the financial model behind Solar for Health is designed to ensure the long-term financial and operational sustainability of solar installations through a coordinated approach. The Solar for Health Coordination Platform aligns donors, governments, private energy service providers (ESPs), and development finance institutions (DFIs) to avoid fragmentation and inefficiencies. To attract private investment and scale impact, the model aggregates projects into investment portfolios with appropriate risk-return profiles, enabling ESPs to access DFI funding through public-private partnerships (PPPs). These partnerships are structured to ensure predictable cash flows—supported by donor contributions and guarantees—which help reduce financial risks. Technical assistance mechanisms complement the financing model by building the capacity of local stakeholders and structuring power purchase agreements (PPAs). This integrated financing approach reduces upfront costs for governments while ensuring long-term service delivery, energy reliability, and resilience across the health sector. content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: All individuals unable to benefit from modern energy services in their households are experiencing energy poverty. This is a global challenge that affects all countries worldwide.

Addressing universal energy access requires a comprehensive understanding of the multiple dimensions of fuel and energy poverty. By improving our understanding of fuel poverty, we can implement targeted interventions and policies that tackle the root causes of energy inequity, ensuring that the benefits of energy access are shared equitably across socio-economic strata.

Accurately measuring energy poverty requires considering multiple factors to fully capture its reality and inform appropriate actions; otherwise, it risks remaining invisible. Various indexes already help track and measure different aspects of energy and fuel poverty, helping to inform effective and inclusive interventions.
